title: Mum-of-two was dying in filth, squalor and pain
text:

A mum-of-two was left to die in a rubbish-filled house, infested with flies and maggots and covered in agonising skin ulcers.

Valerie Wallach's condition was described by paramedics as the "worst condition of a living human they had ever seen."

The 61-year-old ultimately died from breast cancer and multi-organ failure after sitting in a urine and faeces-soiled chair for months.

The mum-of-two was so ill when paramedics and firefighters discovered her that she could no longer speak.

Her husband, 67-year-old Richard Wallach, was jailed today for killing his wife - but neighbours called for sympathy for him.

The Liverpool Echo reports Wallach was jailed for eight years after he was found guilty of manslaughter by gross negligence last month.

(Image: merpol)

The house the couple lived in at Gwendoline Street in Toxteth, was packed to the brim with clutter and rubbish and shocked neighbours who lived a few doors down said they "couldn't believe" what had happened behind closed doors.

The Echo reports Valerie's death "marked the final chapter in a tragic and squalid story which rocked Liverpool."

Neigbours believe Wallach was also ill and some Gwendoline Street residents heartbreakingly did not even know Richard had a wife living with him.

Richard had been described as someone who "kept himself to himself" and did not cause "any bother" for neighbours.

(Image: liverpoolecho.co.uk)

(Image: liverpoolecho.co.uk)

One neighbour, who asked not to be named, said: "They kept themselves to themselves, really. We didn't see anybody, I didn't even know it was them until I read about it on the ECHO.

"They just seemed like nice people, you would not think something like that would have happened.

"You can't say anything nasty about him, you can't say nothing like that. He was just a nice fella you'd see."

The 84-year-old added: "We're just shocked. If that had happened to anybody, you'd be shocked, but if it's someone that lives on your street and you've known them, you just can't explain it."

(Image: liverpoolecho.co.uk)

Valerie died on September 12, 2017, after 19 days in hospital, Liverpool Crown Court was told.

Two other neighbours, who also asked not to be named, said they would see Richard just going "to the chippy" and "getting taxis", but did not know his wife had died.

The uncle and his nephew said they were sympathetic to Richard and said he should have been given help because of the condition the home and Valerie were found in.

The neighbour, who'd lived on the street for 19 years, said: "They should have had people looking after them - we used to see people staying.

"It seems to me that the man is ill, too. You should get some kind of support for that man, they should have had a social worker.

"I'm shocked, I didn't even know the lady had died, I would of never even have known."

He added he and his nephew "would have never suspected it".

Another neighbour, 35, said she was not aware Richard was living with a wife.

(Image: liverpoolecho.co.uk)

(Image: liverpoolecho.co.uk)

The mother, who also asked not to be named, said: "I was not far from what was going on, because I remember the whole house was cordoned off. But we didn't know what had happened and the police did not call us or tell us.

"We were wondering what was going on. We never saw the woman.

"He kept himself to himself, but we always used to see him out. We didn't think that someone was living in that sort of environment though."

The neighbour said she had lived on the Toxteth street for 16 years and said she "couldn't believe" what had happened after learning of Valerie's death.

She added: "It's quite sad she had no one to care for her."

(Image: liverpoolecho.co.uk)

Another neighbour also said she was shocked at Valerie's death and had recalled seeing her out with a dog, years ago.

The Gwendoline Street local, who also asked not to be named, said: "It's come as a shock to me because I didn't know that had happened.

"Sometimes I would see her with her dog and she would always seem friendly."

The Wallachs were married for 15 years and had moved to Liverpool in 2003, having no visitors to the house, and no immediate relatives other than their two children.

Harrowing photos - released after Wallach was found guilty of killing her through gross negligence - reveal the shocking conditions inside the rubbish-filled home.
description: Paramedics found her in the 'worst condition of a living human they had ever seen' in the rubbish-strewn house - but neighbours had no idea she was there
